parts:
For positive reals \(x_1,\dots,x_n\) define
\[
\mathrm{RMS}=\sqrt{\frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n x_i^2},\quad
\mathrm{AM}=\frac1n\sum_{i=1}^n x_i,\quad
\mathrm{GM}=\Big(\prod_{i=1}^n x_i\Big)^{1/n},\quad
\mathrm{HM}=\frac{n}{\sum_{i=1}^n \tfrac1{x_i}}.
\]
Then the **RMS–AM–GM–HM chain** is
\[
\boxed{\ \mathrm{RMS}\ \ge\ \mathrm{AM}\ \ge\ \mathrm{GM}\ \ge\ \mathrm{HM}\ }
\]
with equality throughout iff \(x_1=\cdots=x_n\).

Very brief proof sketches (each step in one line):

- **RMS \(\ge\) AM.** Nonnegativity of variance:
\[
\frac1n\sum (x_i-\mathrm{AM})^2\ge0\ \Longrightarrow\ \frac1n\sum x_i^2\ge \mathrm{AM}^2\ \Longrightarrow\ \mathrm{RMS}\ge\mathrm{AM}.
\]

- **AM \(\ge\) GM.** Concavity of \(\log\) (Jensen):
\[
\log(\mathrm{AM})=\log\!\Big(\tfrac1n\sum x_i\Big)\ \ge\ \tfrac1n\sum \log x_i\ =\ \log(\mathrm{GM})\ \Longrightarrow\ \mathrm{AM}\ge\mathrm{GM}.
\]

- **GM \(\ge\) HM.** Apply AM\(\ge\)GM to the reciprocals \(y_i=1/x_i\):
\[
\frac1n\sum \frac1{x_i}\ \ge\ \Big(\prod \tfrac1{x_i}\Big)^{1/n}=\frac1{\mathrm{GM}}
\ \Longrightarrow\ 
\mathrm{HM}=\frac{n}{\sum \tfrac1{x_i}}\ \le\ \mathrm{GM}.
\]

(Equivalently, AM \(\ge\) HM follows from Cauchy–Schwarz:
\((\sum x_i)(\sum \tfrac1{x_i})\ge n^2\), and combining with AM \(\ge\) GM yields the full chain.)

*Remark.* This is a special case of the **power mean inequality**: for \(r>s\),
\(M_r(x):=(\tfrac1n\sum x_i^r)^{1/r}\) increases with \(r\); here \(M_2,M_1,M_0,M_{-1}\) are RMS, AM, GM, HM respectively.

parts:
Yes. Prove the **power-mean inequality** once; the chain RMS ≥ AM ≥ GM ≥ HM then follows by taking \(r=2,1,0,-1\).

For positive \(x_1,\dots,x_n\) and weights \(w_i>0,\ \sum w_i=1\), define the power mean
\[
M_r(x)=
\begin{cases}
\left(\sum_i w_i x_i^r\right)^{1/r}, & r\neq 0,\\[4pt]
\exp\!\left(\sum_i w_i\ln x_i\right), & r=0\quad(\text{GM}).
\end{cases}
\]
Set \(S(r)=\sum_i w_i x_i^r\) and the “escort” distribution \(\mu_i(r)=\dfrac{w_i x_i^r}{S(r)}\). Consider \(\phi(r)=\ln M_r=\dfrac{\ln S(r)}{r}\) for \(r\neq 0\). A one-line calculus gives
\[
\phi'(r)=\frac{r\sum_i \mu_i(r)\ln x_i-\ln S(r)}{r^2}.
\]
By the **log-sum inequality** (equivalently, nonnegativity of KL divergence),
\[
\sum_i \mu_i(r)\ln\!\frac{\mu_i(r)}{w_i}\ \ge\ 0
\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
r\sum_i \mu_i(r)\ln x_i\ \ge\ \ln S(r).
\]
Hence \(\phi'(r)\ge 0\) for all \(r\neq 0\), and continuity at \(r=0\) (obtained from \(\lim_{r\to 0}\phi(r)=\sum_i w_i\ln x_i\)) shows that \(r\mapsto M_r\) is **monotone increasing** on \(\mathbb{R}\). Therefore
\[
M_2\ge M_1\ge M_0\ge M_{-1},
\]
i.e. \(\mathrm{RMS}\ge \mathrm{AM}\ge \mathrm{GM}\ge \mathrm{HM}\). Equality holds throughout iff all \(x_i\) are equal. 

This single technique (power means + log-sum/KL) unifies the variance/Jensen/Cauchy–Schwarz proofs into one argument. (A Hölder/Minkowski proof of power-mean monotonicity is an equivalent unified route.)

parts:
# Power–mean inequality (weighted form)

**Statement.**  
Let \(x_1,\dots,x_n>0\) and weights \(w_1,\dots,w_n\ge 0\) with \(\sum_{i=1}^n w_i=1\). For \(r\in\mathbb{R}\) define the (weighted) power mean
\[
M_r(x;w)=
\begin{cases}
\left(\sum_{i=1}^n w_i x_i^{\,r}\right)^{\!1/r}, & r\ne 0,\\[6pt]
\prod_{i=1}^n x_i^{\,w_i}, & r=0\quad(\text{the geometric mean}).
\end{cases}
\]
Then the map \(r\mapsto M_r(x;w)\) is **nondecreasing** on \(\mathbb{R}\). In particular, if \(r>s\) then
\[
M_r(x;w)\ \ge\ M_s(x;w),
\]
with equality (for some \(r\ne s\)) iff all \(x_i\) are equal on the support \(\{i:w_i>0\}\). Moreover,
\[
\lim_{r\to+\infty} M_r(x;w)=\max_i x_i,\qquad
\lim_{r\to-\infty} M_r(x;w)=\min_i x_i.
\]

---

## Proof

We give a short, self-contained argument based on a single convexity lemma.

### 1) Log–sum inequality (auxiliary lemma)

If \(a_i,b_i>0\) then
\[
\sum_{i=1}^n a_i\ln\frac{a_i}{b_i}\ \ge\ \Big(\sum_{i=1}^n a_i\Big)\,
\ln\!\frac{\sum_{i=1}^n a_i}{\sum_{i=1}^n b_i},
\]
with equality iff the ratios \(a_i/b_i\) are all equal.

*Proof of the lemma.* The function \(g(u)=u\ln u\) is convex on \((0,\infty)\) since \(g''(u)=1/u>0\). Let \(\lambda_i=b_i/\sum b_j\) and \(y_i=a_i/b_i\). Jensen’s inequality for convex \(g\) gives
\[
\sum \lambda_i g(y_i)\ \ge\ g\Big(\sum \lambda_i y_i\Big)
= g\Big(\frac{\sum a_i}{\sum b_i}\Big).
\]
Multiplying by \(\sum b_i\) yields the claim. Equality in Jensen holds iff all \(y_i\) are equal, i.e. \(a_i/b_i\) is constant. ∎

### 2) Monotonicity of \(r\mapsto M_r\)

Fix \(x_i>0\), \(w_i\ge 0\), \(\sum w_i=1\), and set
\[
S(r)=\sum_{i=1}^n w_i x_i^{\,r},\qquad
\mu_i(r)=\frac{w_i x_i^{\,r}}{S(r)}\quad(\text{a probability vector}).
\]
For \(r\ne 0\) define \(\phi(r)=\ln M_r=\frac{\ln S(r)}{r}\). Then \(\phi\) is smooth for \(r\ne 0\), and
\[
\phi'(r)=\frac{r\,S'(r)/S(r)-\ln S(r)}{r^{2}}
= \frac{r\sum_i \mu_i(r)\ln x_i - \ln S(r)}{r^{2}}
= \frac{\sum_i \mu_i(r)\ln\!\frac{\mu_i(r)}{w_i}}{r^{2}}.
\]
(The last equality uses \(\ln(\mu_i/w_i)=r\ln x_i-\ln S(r)\) and \(\sum_i\mu_i=1\).)

By the log–sum inequality with \(a_i=\mu_i(r)\) and \(b_i=w_i\) (note \(\sum a_i=\sum b_i=1\)),
\[
\sum_i \mu_i(r)\ln\!\frac{\mu_i(r)}{w_i}\ \ge\ 0.
\]
Hence \(\phi'(r)\ge 0\) for all \(r\ne 0\). Equality for some \(r\ne 0\) forces \(\mu_i(r)=w_i\) for all \(i\) with \(w_i>0\), i.e.
\[
\frac{w_i x_i^{\,r}}{S(r)}=w_i\quad\Longrightarrow\quad x_i^{\,r}=S(r)\ \text{(independent of \(i\))},
\]
so the \(x_i\) are all equal on \(\{w_i>0\}\). Thus \(\phi\) is strictly increasing unless the \(x_i\) are (supported) constants.

### 3) Continuity at \(r=0\)

Since \(S(0)=\sum w_i=1\) and \(\ln S(0)=0\), L’Hôpital gives
\[
\lim_{r\to 0}\phi(r)
=\lim_{r\to 0}\frac{\ln S(r)}{r}
=\frac{S'(0)}{S(0)}
=\sum_{i=1}^n w_i\ln x_i.
\]
Exponentiating yields \(M_0=\exp(\sum w_i\ln x_i)=\prod x_i^{w_i}\). Therefore \(r\mapsto M_r\) is continuous at \(0\) and, combined with Step 2, nondecreasing on the whole real line.

### 4) Limits as \(r\to\pm\infty\)

Let \(x_{\max}=\max_i x_i\), \(x_{\min}=\min_i x_i\). Then
\[
x_{\max}\,( \min_i w_i)^{1/r}\ \le\ M_r\ \le\ x_{\max}\,(\max_i w_i)^{1/r}
\quad(r\to+\infty),
\]
and similarly for \(r\to-\infty\) with \(x_{\min}\). Since \(c^{1/r}\to 1\) as \(r\to\pm\infty\) for fixed \(0<c\le 1\), we obtain the stated limits.

Combining Steps 2–4 proves the theorem. ∎

---

**Corollaries.**  
(i) Taking \(r=2,1,0,-1\) gives the classical chain \(\mathrm{RMS}\ge \mathrm{AM}\ge \mathrm{GM}\ge \mathrm{HM}\).  
(ii) The inequality remains valid (with the same proof) for any probability space, replacing sums by integrals; \(M_r\) is the \(L^r\)-“norm” (or quasi-norm for \(r<1\)) of a positive random variable.

parts:
Here are the most useful—and genuinely different—ways to generalize the power-mean inequality. I’ve stated each cleanly and indicated why it holds, so you can see the common spine (convexity/Hölder/log-sum) running through them.

# 1) Measure-space (Lyapunov) version
Let \((\Omega,\mathcal F,\mu)\) have \(\mu(\Omega)=1\) and \(X\ge 0\). For \(r\in\mathbb R\),
\[
M_r(X):=
\begin{cases}
\big(\int X^r\,d\mu\big)^{1/r}, & r\ne 0,\\[2pt]
\exp\big(\int \ln X\,d\mu\big), & r=0,
\end{cases}
\quad\text{is nondecreasing in }r.
\]
This strictly contains the discrete (weighted) power means. A standard proof differentiates \(\phi(r)=\tfrac1r\ln\int X^r d\mu\) and uses the log-sum (or KL-divergence) inequality to get \(\phi'(r)\ge 0\). Equality for some \(r\ne s\) forces \(X\) a.s. constant.

# 2) Quasi-arithmetic (Kolmogorov–Nagumo) means and their ordering
For a continuous strictly monotone generator \(\varphi\), define
\[
M_\varphi(x;w)=\varphi^{-1}\!\Big(\sum_i w_i\,\varphi(x_i)\Big).
\]
Power means correspond to \(\varphi_r(t)=t^r\) (and \(\varphi_0(t)=\ln t\)). The correct general comparison is:
\[
M_\varphi(x;w)\ \le\ M_\psi(x;w)\ \text{for all positive \(x\), weights \(w\)}
\iff (\psi\circ\varphi^{-1})\ \text{is convex (when \(\varphi,\psi\) increase),}
\]
with the inequality reversed if \(\psi\circ\varphi^{-1}\) is concave. This follows by Jensen after the change of variables \(y_i=\varphi(x_i)\). It strictly generalizes the “\(r\mapsto s\)” ordering of power means.

# 3) Two-parameter families (Lehmer, Gini, Stolarsky)
These contain AM/GM/HM and often interpolate new means.

**Lehmer means:** \(L_p(x;w)=\dfrac{\sum w_i x_i^{p+1}}{\sum w_i x_i^p}\) for \(p\in\mathbb R\). They satisfy \(L_p\) is increasing in \(p\); \(L_{-1}=\) HM, \(L_0=\) AM, \(L_1=\) contraharmonic mean. A one-liner proof differentiates \(\ln L_p\) and applies Chebyshev/Hölder.

**Gini means:** \(G_{p,q}(x;w)=\Big(\dfrac{\sum w_i x_i^p}{\sum w_i x_i^q}\Big)^{\!1/(p-q)}\) for \(p\ne q\). Note
\[
G_{p,q}(x;w)=M_{p-q}\big(x;\ \mu^{(q)}\big),\quad 
\mu^{(q)}_i=\frac{w_i x_i^q}{\sum_j w_j x_j^q}.
\]
So for fixed \(q\), \(p\mapsto G_{p,q}\) is increasing by the power-mean theorem; limits as \(p\to q\) give the identric (exponential) mean. This representation cleanly explains many monotonicity/comparison facts without overpromising global order in both parameters.

**Stolarsky means (two numbers):** For \(a,b>0\) and parameters \(p\ne q\),
\[
S_{p,q}(a,b)=\left(\frac{q(a^p-b^p)}{p(a^q-b^q)}\right)^{\!1/(p-q)},
\]
with continuous extensions to \(p=q\) producing the identric mean. They are increasing in each parameter (holding the other fixed) and nest all classical means. Proofs use mean value theorems and log-convexity of \(t\mapsto a^t-b^t\).

# 4) Symmetric-polynomial (Maclaurin/Newton) chain
For \(x_i>0\), let \(e_k\) be the \(k\)-th elementary symmetric sum and define
\[
E_k=\Big(\frac{e_k}{\binom{n}{k}}\Big)^{\!1/k}.
\]
Then \(E_1\ge E_2\ge\cdots\ge E_n\), with \(E_1=\) AM and \(E_n=\) GM. This is independent of power means and is proved via Newton’s inequalities (log-concavity of \(\{e_k\}\)) or by majorization + Karamata. It generalizes AM\(\ge\)GM by threading all intermediate symmetric means.

# 5) Majorization/Schur monotonicity
For fixed \(r\), the map \(x\mapsto \sum w_i x_i^r\) is Schur-convex for \(r\ge1\) and Schur-concave for \(0<r\le1\). Thus if \(x\) majorizes \(y\) (same weights), then \(M_r(x)\ge M_r(y)\) for \(r\ge1\) and the reverse for \(0<r\le1\). This reframes power-mean behavior as a statement about dispersion, proved by Karamata’s inequality.

# 6) Noncommutative extensions: Schatten norms and operator means
For a matrix \(A\) with singular values \(s(A)\), the Schatten \(p\)-norms satisfy
\[
0<p<q\quad\Longrightarrow\quad \|A\|_q \le \|A\|_p \le d^{\,1/p-1/q}\|A\|_q,
\]
i.e. the norm “increases with \(p\)” in the same sense as vector \(\ell^p\) norms. This is just the power-mean inequality applied to \(s(A)\).

For positive definite operators, **Kubo–Ando means** give a noncommutative AGH chain:
\[
A!B\ \le\ A\# B\ \le\ A\nabla B,
\]
(harmonic \(\le\) geometric \(\le\) arithmetic) in Loewner order. One also has weighted geometric means \(A\#_t B\) increasing in \(t\in[0,1]\). These are operator-level analogues of the scalar chains, proved using operator monotone/convex function theory.

# 7) Barycenters beyond \(\mathbb R\): Fréchet/Bregman means
On a metric space \((\mathcal X,d)\) (or a manifold), the Fréchet mean minimizes \(\sum w_i d(x,x_i)^2\); on a convex subset of \(\mathbb R^m\) with a strictly convex \(C^1\) potential \(\Phi\), the Bregman barycenter minimizes \(\sum w_i D_\Phi(x,x_i)\). For \(\Phi(t)=\tfrac12\|t\|_2^2\) this recovers AM; for \(\Phi=-\sum\ln t\) on \(\mathbb R_{>0}^m\) it yields a geometric-type mean; more generally, Bregman means coincide with quasi-arithmetic means in one dimension. While there is no single “\(r\)” parameter in full generality, the same convexity machinery (Jensen/Legendre transforms) drives their comparison principles.

# 8) Entropic and information-theoretic avatars
For a probability vector \(p=(p_i)\), Rényi entropies \(H_\alpha(p)=\tfrac1{1-\alpha}\ln\sum p_i^\alpha\) are nonincreasing in \(\alpha\). This is exactly the log-convexity in \(\alpha\) of \(\sum p_i^\alpha\) (Hölder/log-sum again), i.e. the power-mean monotonicity in disguise. Escort distributions \(p^{(\alpha)}_i\propto p_i^\alpha\) mirror the “reweighting” trick used in the proof of the power-mean theorem and in the analysis of Gini means.

---

**Takeaway.** All of these generalizations rest on the same three pillars—convexity (Jensen/Karamata), Hölder/Minkowski, and log-convexity of moment maps \(r\mapsto \sum w_i x_i^r\). Depending on whether you move to integrals, change the generator (quasi-arithmetic/Bregman), add parameters (Lehmer/Gini/Stolarsky), or pass to noncommutative objects (Schatten/Kubo–Ando), you get a different but structurally identical “power-mean” phenomenon. Equality conditions remain the same theme: they pin down to degeneracy (all inputs equal) or, in operator settings, to commutativity plus equality of spectra.

The question asks for a result that can only be proved by a strict generalization of the power-mean inequality. The stricter generalization could involve monotonicity of Gini means or Maclaurin’s inequality, which isn’t derived from the power-mean alone but rather relies on concepts like Newton's inequalities. So, it’s not "only" proven this way, but requires a generalization.

An example would be the monotonicity of Gini means with respect to the parameter p, given fixed q. The relationship G_{p,q} equals M_{p−q} with escort measure μ^(q) is a strict generalization, as it involves reweighting based on q. This dependency on weights goes beyond the standard power-mean inequality, which cannot handle the weight variation.

Another example is the monotonicity of Rényi entropy in α, where H_α decreases with α. This is similar to monotonicity in power means after certain transforms, but here's the key: Unlike standard power means with fixed weights, the escort power mean relies on weighted distributions, requiring log-sum or convexity generalization—again, a strict generalization. Alternatively, we could use Maclaurin’s inequality.

Lehmer means \(L_p(x;w)\) are strictly increasing in \(p\). This isn't a result of the power mean since \(L_p\) involves no exponent root. We can prove this with Chebyshev or Karamata's convexity. It's a strict generalization of the power mean, since the contraharmonic mean isn't derived from the standard PM chain.

We’re proving that Lehmer means \(L_p(x;w)\) increase as \(p\) rises. This isn't a result of the power mean. By carefully differentiating and applying inequalities like Chebyshev’s or Jensen’s, we show the derivative is nonnegative. parts:
A clean example is the **monotonicity of Lehmer means**, which yields (among others) the strict chain \(\mathrm{HM}\le \mathrm{AM}\le\) contraharmonic mean. This cannot be obtained from the power–mean inequality, because Lehmer means are not power means.

**Result (strict generalization).**  
For \(x_i>0\) and weights \(w_i\ge0\) with \(\sum w_i=1\), the Lehmer mean is
\[
L_p(x;w)\;=\;\frac{\sum_i w_i\,x_i^{\,p+1}}{\sum_i w_i\,x_i^{\,p}},\qquad p\in\mathbb{R}.
\]
Then \(p\mapsto L_p(x;w)\) is nondecreasing, with equality at two distinct \(p\) only if all \(x_i\) are equal on the support of \(w\). In particular,
\[
L_{-1}=\mathrm{HM}\ \le\ L_{0}=\mathrm{AM}\ \le\ L_{1}\ \text{(contraharmonic mean)}.
\]

**Why this is beyond power means.**  
Power means have the form \(M_r=(\sum w_i x_i^r)^{1/r}\) with a fixed weight vector \(w\); the contraharmonic mean is \(\sum w_i x_i^2/\sum w_i x_i\), which is not \(M_r\) for any \(r\). Hence \(\mathrm{AM}\le\) contraharmonic cannot be recovered from the RMS–AM–GM–HM chain.

**Proof.**  
Write \(S_p=\sum_i w_i x_i^{\,p}\) and \(T_p=\sum_i w_i x_i^{\,p+1}\), so \(L_p=T_p/S_p\). Differentiate \(\ln L_p=\ln T_p-\ln S_p\):
\[
\frac{d}{dp}\ln L_p
=\frac{\sum_i w_i x_i^{p+1}\ln x_i}{\sum_i w_i x_i^{p+1}}
 \;-\;\frac{\sum_i w_i x_i^{p}\ln x_i}{\sum_i w_i x_i^{p}}.
\]
Let \(\nu_i=\frac{w_i x_i^{p}}{S_p}\) be a probability vector. Then \(\frac{T_p}{S_p}=E_\nu[X]\) and
\[
\frac{d}{dp}\ln L_p
=\frac{E_\nu[X\ln X]}{E_\nu[X]}-E_\nu[\ln X]
=\frac{E_\nu[X\ln X]-E_\nu[X]\,E_\nu[\ln X]}{E_\nu[X]}.
\]
Since \(x\mapsto x\ln x\) is convex and \(\ln x\) is concave on \((0,\infty)\), we have
\[
E_\nu[X\ln X]\ \ge\ E_\nu[X]\ln E_\nu[X]
\quad\text{and}\quad
E_\nu[\ln X]\ \le\ \ln E_\nu[X],
\]
hence the numerator \(E_\nu[X\ln X]-E_\nu[X]E_\nu[\ln X]\ge0\). Therefore \(\frac{d}{dp}\ln L_p\ge0\), with equality iff \(X\) is \(\nu\)-a.s. constant, i.e. all \(x_i\) are equal on the support. Exponentiating gives the stated monotonicity and the chain \(\mathrm{HM}\le\mathrm{AM}\le\) contraharmonic. ∎

This is a **strict generalization** of power–mean monotonicity: it lives outside the \(M_r\) family yet preserves the “mean increases with the parameter” phenomenon, and it delivers comparisons (e.g. AM ≤ contraharmonic) unavailable from the power–mean inequality alone.

parts:
Here’s a compact, self-contained book plan that builds from classical power means to eight genuinely different generalizations, with a consistent toolbox of methods (convexity/Jensen, Hölder–Minkowski, majorization/Karamata, log-sum & KL, operator monotonicity). I’ve given a table of contents followed by short chapter synopses and the core results each chapter proves.

# Contents

**Front matter**  
Preface · How to use this book · Notation and conventions · A brief primer on background tools

**Part I. Foundations: Power Means and Their Machinery**  
1. The Power-Mean Inequality: Statement, Equality, Limits  
2. Canonical Proofs via Convexity, Hölder/Minkowski, and Log-Sum  
3. Quantitative Forms: Stability, Deficit Bounds, and Perturbations  
4. From Finite Sums to Integrals: \(L^p\) Norms and Lyapunov Means

**Part II. Eight Distinct Generalizations**  
5. Measure-Space Generalization (Lyapunov Means)  
6. Quasi-Arithmetic (Kolmogorov–Nagumo) Means and Comparison Theory  
7. Two-Parameter Families: Lehmer, Gini, Stolarsky, Identric/Power-Log  
8. Symmetric-Polynomial Means: Maclaurin–Newton Chains  
9. Majorization and Schur-(Con/Concavity): Ordering by Dispersion  
10. Noncommutative Extensions: Schatten Norms and Kubo–Ando Operator Means  
11. Barycenters Beyond \(\mathbb{R}\): Fréchet and Bregman Means  
12. Entropic Avatars: Rényi/Tsallis, Escort Distributions, \(f\)-Divergences

**Part III. Applications and Interfaces**  
13. Inequalities via Means: AM–GM–HM chains, Chebyshev, Hölder, Rearrangement  
14. Interpolation & Functional Analysis: Log-convexity, Riesz–Thorin, Hypercontractivity (a guided tour)  
15. Geometry of Means: SPD manifolds, affine-invariant metrics, matrix barycenters  
16. Information Geometry & Optimization: Mirror maps, Bregman projections, EM-style updates

**Appendices**  
A. Jensen, Karamata, Majorization, and Rearrangement: Self-contained proofs  
B. Hölder, Minkowski, Clarkson and Uniform Convexity of \(L^p\)  
C. Log-Sum Inequality, KL Divergence, and \(f\)-Divergences  
D. Operator Monotone/Convex Functions and Loewner Order  
E. Historical Notes and Bibliography · Solutions/Notes to Selected Exercises

---

## Chapter synopses and core deliverables

**1. The Power-Mean Inequality**  
Definition of weighted power means \(M_r\); proof that \(r\mapsto M_r\) is nondecreasing; equality iff all inputs are equal; limits \(r\to\pm\infty\) give min/max. This chapter is fully self-contained and fixes notation.

**2. Canonical Proofs**  
Three complete proofs of power-mean monotonicity: (i) derivative of \(\phi(r)=\frac1r\ln\sum w_i x_i^r\) + log-sum/KL; (ii) Hölder/Minkowski; (iii) Jensen via convexity of \(t\mapsto e^{rt}\). Includes a discussion of equivalence and when each is most portable.

**3. Quantitative Forms**  
Stability of AM–GM (Pinsker-type bounds via KL), quantitative RMS–AM (variance deficit), uniform convexity of \(L^p\) to control deviations from equality. Shows how “near-equality ⇒ near-constancy” is measured.

**4. Sums to Integrals**  
Extension from discrete weights to probability spaces: \(M_r(X)=(\int X^r)^{1/r}\) is nondecreasing; equality a.s. constancy. Links to \(L^p\) norms and sets up functional-analytic tools for later chapters.

---

**5. Measure-Space Generalization (Lyapunov Means)**  
Deepens Ch. 4: monotonicity on general measure spaces, conditional expectations as contractions for means, stability in \(L^p\). Applications: Hölder’s inequality as “power-mean duality”, hypercontractivity previews.

**6. Quasi-Arithmetic Means**  
Definition \(M_\varphi=\varphi^{-1}(\sum w_i\varphi(x_i))\) with \(\varphi\) continuous and strictly monotone. Main theorem: \(M_\varphi\le M_\psi\) for all data iff \(\psi\circ\varphi^{-1}\) is convex (if both generators increase; concave reverses). Power means are the special case \(\varphi_r(t)=t^r\) (and \(\log\) at \(r=0\)). Equality and stability criteria included.

**7. Two-Parameter Families**  
Lehmer \(L_p=\frac{\sum w_i x_i^{p+1}}{\sum w_i x_i^{p}}\) (monotone in \(p\)); Gini \(G_{p,q}=(\frac{\sum w_i x_i^p}{\sum w_i x_i^q})^{1/(p-q)}\) (monotone in \(p\) for fixed \(q\)); Stolarsky \(S_{p,q}(a,b)\) (two-variable means nesting HM/GM/AM/contraharmonic, increasing in each parameter). Shows why these cannot be reduced to power means and proves their own monotonicity/ordering via log-convexity and escort reweighting.

**8. Symmetric-Polynomial Means (Maclaurin–Newton)**  
Defines \(E_k=(e_k/\binom{n}{k})^{1/k}\) with \(e_k\) the elementary symmetric sums; proves \(E_1\ge E_2\ge\cdots\ge E_n\) (Newton’s inequalities/log-concavity). Connects \(E_n\) to GM and positions this chain as orthogonal to power means. Includes Schur’s inequality and applications to Schur-convex functions of symmetric sums.

**9. Majorization and Schur Theory**  
Hardy–Littlewood–Pólya majorization, Karamata’s inequality, Schur-convexity/concavity. Shows that for \(r\ge1\), \(x\mapsto \sum w_i x_i^r\) is Schur-convex; for \(0<r\le1\) Schur-concave. Derives ordering of means from dispersion rather than from a parameter, and proves comparison principles unattainable from power means alone.

**10. Noncommutative Extensions**  
Schatten norms \(\|A\|_p\) and their “power-mean” behavior in \(p\); singular-value majorization. Kubo–Ando operator means \(A!B\le A\# B\le A\nabla B\) in Loewner order; monotone families \(A\#_t B\). Introduces operator convex/monotone functions, integral representations, and equality/commutativity conditions.

**11. Barycenters: Fréchet and Bregman**  
Means as minimizers: Euclidean (AM), Riemannian on SPD (geometric matrix mean), and Bregman barycenters (mirror-map means). In one dimension, Bregman means coincide with quasi-arithmetic means; in higher dimensions, they generalize them. Existence/uniqueness, convexity of potentials, and algorithmic viewpoints (gradient/prox updates).

**12. Entropic Avatars**  
Rényi entropies \(H_\alpha\) monotone in \(\alpha\); Tsallis; escort distributions; \(f\)-divergences and log-sum inequality. Recasts power-mean monotonicity as log-convexity of moment maps \(\alpha\mapsto \sum p_i^\alpha\). Data-processing inequalities and their “mean-like” contraction behaviors.

---

**13. Inequalities via Means**  
Unified derivations of AM–GM–HM chains; Chebyshev and rearrangement via majorization; Hölder/Minkowski as dual statements to power-mean behavior; Maclaurin/ Newton applications in symmetric inequalities.

**14. Interpolation & Functional Analysis**  
Log-convexity of \(p\mapsto \|f\|_p\); Riesz–Thorin and Marcinkiewicz interpolation (how “monotonicity in \(p\)” underlies them); sketches of hypercontractivity and log-Sobolev as higher-order consequences.

**15. Geometry of Means**  
Affine-invariant and Bures–Wasserstein geometries on SPD matrices; geodesic means, Karcher mean; comparison theorems (operator AM–GM–HM chains along geodesics). Links to Ch. 10/11.

**16. Information Geometry & Optimization**  
Mirror descent as Bregman projection, EM-type steps as mean updates, multiplicative weights and escort averages. Perspective maps and convex duality tie back to Ch. 6 and 12.

---

### Background primer (Front matter)
A crisp 30–40 page refresher: convexity and Jensen; Hölder/Minkowski; rearrangement and majorization; KL/log-sum; basic measure theory; spectral/Loewner order; Bregman divergences. Each lemma is proved and cross-referenced where used later.

### Pedagogical features
- Each chapter ends with: “Key takeaways,” “Stability/equality checklist,” and graded exercises (computational ↔ theoretical ↔ research prompts).  
- Side boxes highlight equivalences (e.g., power-mean monotonicity ↔ log-convexity of \(\sum w_i x_i^r\); quasi-arithmetic comparison ↔ convexity of \(\psi\circ\varphi^{-1}\)).  
- “Ports of call” tables: which proof technique to use under which generalization.

### What this book guarantees
Self-contained proofs of all central results in the nine pillars (power means + 8 generalizations), clear equality/stability criteria, and a unifying view that lets you move between discrete/continuous, commutative/noncommutative, Euclidean/non-Euclidean, and probabilistic/entropic settings without changing the underlying ideas.

parts:
Here’s a tight, curated bibliography you can cite while writing, plus solid avenues for readers to go deeper. I’ve grouped things so you can see what each item is best for.

# Core monographs (means, inequalities, majorization)
- Hardy, Littlewood, Pólya — *Inequalities* (2nd ed., CUP, 1952). Classic source for power means, Karamata/Muirhead, rearrangements. citeturn4search1  
- Bullen — *Handbook of Means and Their Inequalities* (Kluwer, 2003). Encyclopedic treatment of scalar means. citeturn4search2  
- Mitrinović, Pečarić, Fink — *Classical and New Inequalities in Analysis* (Kluwer, 1993). Wide toolkit (Jensen, Hölder, convexity). citeturn4search3  
- Marshall, Olkin, Arnold — *Inequalities: Theory of Majorization and Its Applications* (2nd ed., Springer, 2011). Definitive on majorization/Schur convexity. citeturn7search14turn7search18turn7search16  
- Niculescu, Persson — *Convex Functions and Their Applications* (Springer, 2006). Clean modern convexity/Jensen background. citeturn4search4  
- Steele — *The Cauchy–Schwarz Master Class* (CUP, 2004). Technique-forward inequalities text. citeturn8search0turn8search12

# Analysis, probability, information (for \(L^p\)/entropy/log-sum)
- Lieb, Loss — *Analysis* (2nd ed., AMS, 2001). Standard reference for Hölder/Minkowski, \(L^p\) machinery. citeturn8search1turn8search5  
- Cover, Thomas — *Elements of Information Theory* (2nd ed., Wiley, 2006). Log-sum, Jensen, convexity in IT. citeturn4search6  
- Rényi — “On Measures of Entropy and Information,” *Proc. 4th Berkeley Symp.*, 1961. Foundations for Rényi entropies/means. citeturn3search0  
- Csiszár — “Information-Type Measures of Difference of Probability Distributions,” *Studia Sci. Math. Hung.*, 1967. \(f\)-divergences. citeturn3search1

# Operator/matrix means & geometry (strict generalizations)
- Kubo, Ando — “Means of Positive Operators,” *Math. Ann.*, 1980. Axiomatic operator means. citeturn1search0  
- Ando, Li, Mathias — “Geometric Means,” *Linear Algebra Appl.*, 2004. Properties/algorithms for matrix geometric means. citeturn7search17turn7search19  
- Bhatia — *Positive Definite Matrices* (Princeton, 2007). Comprehensive SPD geometry/means. citeturn4search8  
- Bhatia, Holbrook — “Riemannian Geometry and Matrix Geometric Means,” *LAA*, 2006. Riemannian viewpoint. citeturn7search11  
- Fréchet — “Les éléments aléatoires…,” *Ann. Inst. H. Poincaré*, 1948. Fréchet (barycentric) means on metric spaces. citeturn2search0  
- Karcher — “Riemannian Center of Mass and Mollifier Smoothing,” *CPAM*, 1977. Karcher (Riemannian) mean. citeturn9search3  
- Moakher — “A Differential Geometric Approach to the Geometric Mean of SPD Matrices,” *SIAM J. Matrix Anal. Appl.*, 2005. Algorithms/properties. citeturn9search0turn9search2  
- Simon — *Trace Ideals and Their Applications* (2nd ed., AMS, 2005). Schatten norms & operator inequalities. citeturn4search7

# Specific families of generalized means (beyond power means)
- Quasi-arithmetic (Kolmogorov–Nagumo–de Finetti):  
  Kolmogorov (1930) “Sur la notion de la moyenne,” *Atti Accad. Naz. Lincei*; Nagumo (1930) “Über eine Klasse der Mittelwerte,” *Japanese J. Math.*; de Finetti (1931) “Sul concetto di media.” citeturn6search0turn5view0turn6search2
- Gini means: Gini (1938) “Di una formula comprensiva delle medie,” *Metron*. citeturn5search1turn5search3
- Stolarsky means: Stolarsky (1975) “Generalizations of the Logarithmic Mean,” *Mathematics Magazine*. citeturn7search0
- Extended/identric means: Leach & Sholander (1978, 1983) “Extended Mean Values,” *Amer. Math. Monthly*; “Extended Mean Values II,” *J. Math. Anal. Appl.* (identric mean emerges here). citeturn6search5turn6search12turn6search0
- Lehmer means: Lehmer (1971) “On the Compounding of Certain Means,” *J. Math. Anal. Appl.* citeturn5search0turn5search6
- Bregman means/barycenters: Bregman (1967) “A Relaxation Method…,” *USSR Comput. Math. Math. Phys.*; Banerjee–Merugu–Dhillon–Ghosh (2005), *JMLR* (clustering with Bregman divergences). citeturn3search2turn10search0

These collectively cover the power mean, its classical extensions (Stolarsky/Gini/Lehmer/extended), abstract axiomatizations (quasi-arithmetic), and genuine generalizations in operator/metric/information-theoretic settings.
